body: All other solutions I know of are hacks that kinda work (usually by creating a new split and then deleting the buffer in that window, and attempting to cover all possible cases for this), but intrinsic support for this would be greatly appreciated.

comment_data.body:
> usually by creating a new split and then deleting the buffer in that window

That isn't necessary at all. The hack I use switches to the next valid buffer (or creates a new empty one), then deletes the original. I'm planning to release it as part of a plugin...

@justinmk I think you'll find [it's](http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Deleting_a_buffer_without_closing_the_window) [been](https://github.com/moll/vim-bbye) [done](https://github.com/rbgrouleff/bclose.vim) [already](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4465095/vim-delete-buffer-without-losing-the-split-window) [in many different ways](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4298910/vim-close-buffer-but-not-split-window).

The fact that you call it a hack would seem to support this even more. It doesn't seem like it should be difficult to implement. *And is more something that should be core functionality than a plugin really.
Yes, I know. But the idea of adding a new core command for this doesn't sound appealing. Details would be welcome though.

`:enew!`?

> Edit a new, unnamed buffer.  Discard any changes to the current buffer.
Why not simply implement this as a buffer option?

> A whole terminal was added along with autocommands, a command, and a Terminal class. This is incredibly light weight in comparison.

I'm talking about the UI, not the technical cost, and in _proportion_ to the benefit. The technical and UI cost of `:terminal` in relation to its benefit is worth it. Adding `:bdelete_but_leave_my_window_alone` may not be.

> bclose is not taken AFAIK,

So what about someone who wants to `:bwipe` or `:bunload` without closing the window? 

> Why not simply implement this as a buffer option?

Users will still need to wrap that option in a command, so it doesn't gain anything over the current situation.

> enew! doesn't close the buffer with set hidden

But this does:

```
set bufhidden=delete
enew!
```

@justinmk I guess `set bufhidden=delete | bnext | set bufhidden=hide` (or a function which uses a variable to save the value instead of using `hide`) does what I want pretty well. I can see how this would be difficult to add now without breaking anything.

What I dislike is how a person who wants this functionality in Vim will have to search the internet and try to find one that works or be familiar enough with vim to have considered the optimal solution. It seems a common enough thing people try to do that it shouldn't require that much effort.

> `set bufhidden=delete | bnext | set bufhidden=hide`

`set bufhidden=hide` should not be necessary because it's a buffer-local variable :)

So this should be a complete solution:

```
setl bufhidden=delete | bnext
```
@justinmk good to know.

> setl bufhidden=delete | bnext

Really simple, no need for a separate option just to achieve that :smile:

Not entirely true, when you have two windows open displaying the buffer you want to delete, 'bd' deletes the buffer (and both windows), while 'setl bufhidden=delete | bnext' only goes to the next buffer in the current window and nothing more.

Edit: Of course the buffer is still being marked as bufhidden=delete, so :bnext in the other window will delete the buffer then.
@HarmtH I've realized this as I've been writing this plugin for the past 20 minutes. It seems it's more nuance than I thought. You have to make sure no windows are pointing at the buffer.

@HarmtH I initially thought `vim-bbye` was using a different method, but after using it, I see that it covers all the cases. It may be that such a thing would have been useful in the core, but I suppose the plugin...will do.

Where can I find vim-bbyte? I've looked at multiple plugins that try to do this correctly, but they all have their problems.

In my opinion this should be a core option of (N)Vim too. New commands would be nice, so it doesn't break plugins that rely on bd/bw/bun to close a split window (do they exist?), but probably an option like 'keepwindow' will suffice too.

I also think the proposed feature would be extremely useful:
when programming in python, I have to windows side by side, sometimes I quickly want an ipython console in second window, hence:
`:e term://ipython3`
but if I quit the interpreter, the window layout is destroyed.
Can't see how
`setl bufhidden=delete | bnext`
could solve that.

@weichm What proposed feature? Nothing concrete was actually proposed. 

The request can't be achieved with just one new command, see [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2434#issuecomment-93418010). Can't be just one new option either. 

Should we add 4 new options/commands for this?

Something that might work: a global option that says "always preserve windows when deleting/wiping/unloading buffers".

> :e term://ipython3
> but if I quit the interpreter, the window layout is destroyed.

Only if you delete the buffer. You can exit terminal-mode with CTRL-\ CTRL-N instead.

@justinmk 
> What proposed feature? Nothing concrete was actually proposed.

I mean "command/function to delete buffer without closing the window"

> Only if you delete the buffer. You can exit terminal-mode with CTRL-\ CTRL-N instead.

Let's say I have a fixed window layout and want to frequently (say 10 times) switch in 2nd window between execute `e term://date` and edit somefile. If I am getting you right, I have 10 absolutely irrelevant date buffers.

I have no idea what a feasible solution would look like for neovim, nor a simple way to get around that.

> I have 10 absolutely irrelevant date buffers.

There's nothing wrong with that. Buffers are data structures, they should not be treated like special pets, in Vim.

Just give us option:
`set noscrewmylayout`
This behavior is most ridiculous and unwanted feature in Vim. Even Vim guys understand this and added bclose command (not better solution, option will be better).

> Even Vim guys understand this and added bclose command (not better solution, option will be better)

What "blcose" command are you talking about? Please link to the commit or docs.
Sorry, i was wrong. Bclose is third party solution. So, vim guys don't understand how this feature awful. Still, please give us setting to disable this senseless behavior.
I will send 10$ if this option will be added. I will send 20$ if this option will be called `noscrewmylayout`

i pulled my hair over this, and that brought me here as well, so im just adding my 2 cents.
I know there are a bunch of hacks/plugins that enable the right functionality, but quite honestly, it feels like fixing your ferrari with duct-tape.
my impression is that original vim developers made a poor design decision by having their buffer commands have anything to do with closing windows that display the buffer. buffers are for loading in memory, and windows are for viewing; those are completely separate things and shouldn't have been intertwined so badly.
in my opinion, window layout (splits, tabs) should not be touched by buffer commands and vice-versa. open windows should remain open, unless you use a window command, buffers should remain loaded unless you use a buffer command.
Then if we want a specific behavior like the traditional :bd, we can use a combination of window and buffer commands.
Rather than drag along an old illogical design decision, I think nvim should go in this direction, and keep the :bd behavior compatibility as part of a bundled plugin that uses some buffer and window commands.

Me too landed here because I was googling why nvim closes the window although the command is called bd and I assume b stands for buffer (and not window) and d stands for delete (and not close). 

So just looking at the name the behavior is not correct.

Recently I started to look up how to use buffers/windows/tabs correctly. I'm not there yet but as I understand it a window is just a place where a buffer is shown. So if the buffer is closed/deleted the window should remain open, just as it does if I have no splits (window remains open, at least it looks like that... ).

So looking at the behavior with no splits compared to behavior with splits it is not consistent.

This behavior is not intuitive too and in contrast to some other vim stuff that is not intuitive but still makes sense as you grasp the idea behind it.

And lastly, I try to embrace the vim style of doing things all the time. So if you can tell me what the vim way of "keep the window and just close the damn buffer" is I would appreciate that. Otherwise there should at least be a single command that does the right thing and in best case the bd command does what the name suggests and another one is added that mimics the old behavior if someone needs it.

Ill donate 10$ for the option to have correct behavior and 30 if the bd command is changed to do what the name suggest :)

PS: I use the following as a workaround, which actually works good enough for me, although I am only using it for few minutes.
" use ctrl+x to close buffer
nnoremap <C-x> :bnext<CR>:bd#<CR>

Oh wow, I got a notification on this issue today and I didn't realize that I was the original creator. FYI, I can do this with lua and it's pretty much exactly what I want. Now that I'm on the neovim team, maybe we can add this to the core, but here it is for anyone who's interested:

```lua
local api = vim.api

local function nvim_loaded_buffers()
  local result = {}
  local buffers = api.nvim_list_bufs()
  for _, buf in ipairs(buffers) do
    if api.nvim_buf_is_loaded(buf) then
      table.insert(result, buf)
    end
  end
  return result
end

-- Kill the target buffer (or the current one if 0/nil)
function buf_kill(target_buf, should_force)
  if not should_force and vim.bo.modified then
    return api.nvim_err_writeln('Buffer is modified. Force required.')
  end
  local command = 'bd'
  if should_force then command = command..'!' end
  if target_buf == 0 or target_buf == nil then
    target_buf = api.nvim_get_current_buf()
  end
  local buffers = nvim_loaded_buffers()
  if #buffers == 1 then
    api.nvim_command(command)
    return
  end
  local nextbuf
  for i, buf in ipairs(buffers) do
    if buf == target_buf then
      nextbuf = buffers[(i - 1 + 1) % #buffers + 1]
      break
    end
  end
  api.nvim_set_current_buf(nextbuf)
  api.nvim_command(table.concat({command, target_buf}, ' '))
end
```

This is how I use it.

```vim
" normal kill
nnoremap <a-c> <Cmd>lua buf_kill(0)<CR>
" force kill
nnoremap <a-s-c> <Cmd>lua buf_kill(0, true)<CR>
```

It will unload the current buffer and switch to another buffer without closing the window.

E: Also donate your money to the [neovim team](https://www.bountysource.com/teams/neovim) or your favorite charity instead.
I will donate only if there will be single option value. I already have my own hacks (and you can easily find lot of them). But i don't like hacks, i need real solution.

It's not really a hack for my use case where I want to have the option to either close the window or not. Since you want it to be some kind of default mode option @kasymovga, I recommend opening a new issue, because I would consider this one to be closed.
This would not be implemented as an option, that would break plugins. Instead it could be a new command, I'm thinking `ZB` (analogous to `ZZ` and `ZQ`).

For the Ex command, i would suggest adding a modifier comparable to ```:keepjumps``` and ```:keepmarks```, let's say ```:keepwindows```.

Then it won't only be useful for ```:bdelete```, but also for ```:bunload```, ```:bwipeout```, and maybe other commands.

I almost made a duplicate issue related to this. I also hate the default behaviour of `:bdelete`, `:bunload` and `:bwipeout`.

> This would not be implemented as an option, that would break plugins.

@justinmk How about if a new option is added, but the default value of the option would keep the behaviour backwards compatible?

The user can then choose to
- not touch the option (plugins will work as usual because of the backwards compatibility) or
- set the option so that the previously mentioned commands respect the window layout. If this breaks users favourite plugins, the user can set the option back to the default value, or/and make a new issue to the plugin development forum, which can have the effect that the new option is taken into an account in the next version of the plugin, after which the user can again set the non-default value for the option.

I also like the idea of `ZB`, but to me it only makes sense if it has a corresponding Ex command, like `ZZ` and `ZQ` do. I think `:bdelete` would be the most reasonable one. I think it would also make sense to write the current file before deleting the buffer.

Re: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2434#issuecomment-565577489
shouldn't `if #buffers == 1 then ...` be actually `if #buffers == 0 then ...`? Cause you're checking it after the target buffer already `bd`ed. At least for me that causes an empty split when `buf_kill(0)` one buffer out of two each open in its own split.
Additionally your script only maintains the currently active window with the buf to kill. All other windows that may happen to have the same buf open will be shut.
